text: I use Lightsail - as far as I can tell it's just a lighter weight skin on AWS.  Simpler website/interface etc.  I'm only using a single VM and MySQL instance, so it suits me.  If you had a more complex infrastructure the limited functionality would get pretty annoying pretty quickly.

elements.text: I use Lightsail - as far as I can tell it's just a lighter weight skin on AWS.  Simpler website/interface etc.  I'm only using a single VM and MySQL instance, so it suits me.  If you had a more complex infrastructure the limited functionality would get pretty annoying pretty quickly.

text:
SrFabio when you say hedging are you talking about placing your first back bet under 2.5 goals and then at a later date when the odds have shifted you want to place a back bet over 2.5 goals and hedge your bets such that you green up evenly ?

If this is the case then I assume you have the formular to do this.

elements.text:
SrFabio when you say hedging are you talking about placing your first back bet under 2.5 goals and then at a later date when the odds have shifted you want to place a back bet over 2.5 goals and hedge your bets such that you green up evenly ?

If this is the case then I assume you have the formular to do this.

text:
I should also add I assume cross matching market meaning instead of placing the 2nd back bet at over 2.5 you should also be able to lay the under 2.5.

The following I use for racing but applicable for any market

FAVOUR AN EQUAL RESULT THEREFORE WIN AMOUNT FOR WINNING RUNNER = WIN AMOUNT FOR LOSING RUNNER ie GREEN BOTH SIDES

$Rwin   = $Rloss
$Rwin   = Back_Profit - Lay_Liability
$Rloss  = Lay_Profit - Back_Liabiltiy

Bo = Back Odds
Bs = Back Size
Bp Back Profit
Lo = Lay Odds
Ls = Lay Size
Ll = Lay Liability

Bp  - Ll    = Lp - Bl
(Bo-1).Bs   - (Lo-1).Ls     = Ls - Bs

SOLVE FOR Bo
(Bo-1).Bs   = Ls - Bs + (Lo - 1).Ls
(Bo-1).Bs   = Ls - Bs +  <http://Lo.Ls|Lo.Ls> - Ls
(Bo-1).Bs   =    - Bs +  <http://Lo.Ls|Lo.Ls>
(Bo-1)      = (<http://Lo.Ls|Lo.Ls> - Bs) / Bs
Bo  = (<http://Lo.Ls|Lo.Ls> - Bs) / Bs     + 1

elements.text:
I should also add I assume cross matching market meaning instead of placing the 2nd back bet at over 2.5 you should also be able to lay the under 2.5.

The following I use for racing but applicable for any market

FAVOUR AN EQUAL RESULT THEREFORE WIN AMOUNT FOR WINNING RUNNER = WIN AMOUNT FOR LOSING RUNNER ie GREEN BOTH SIDES

$Rwin   = $Rloss
$Rwin   = Back_Profit - Lay_Liability
$Rloss  = Lay_Profit - Back_Liabiltiy

Bo = Back Odds
Bs = Back Size
Bp Back Profit
Lo = Lay Odds
Ls = Lay Size
Ll = Lay Liability

Bp  - Ll    = Lp - Bl
(Bo-1).Bs   - (Lo-1).Ls     = Ls - Bs

SOLVE FOR Bo
(Bo-1).Bs   = Ls - Bs + (Lo - 1).Ls
(Bo-1).Bs   = Ls - Bs +  Lo.Ls - Ls
(Bo-1).Bs   =    - Bs +  Lo.Ls
(Bo-1)      = (Lo.Ls - Bs) / Bs
Bo  = (Lo.Ls - Bs) / Bs     + 1

text: You also rearrange the formualr to solve Bs, Lo or Ls provided you have the other 3 variables.  If you get stuck send me an XLS spreadsheet with your setup and I can create the formular and show you it in the XLS itself.

text:
Thanks for sharing this, it looks a bit different then mine but I think it achieves the same. Later on today I'll try this implementation to see if it makes a difference.
Regarding the scenario I mentioned, the second bet (back over 2.5) is not really to hedge evenly, but it would put both selections on profit, it's the third bet that should do the hedging and I'm not getting it right (apparently) - Given a selection with at least one order
1. Check if we are on a back/lay or lay/back scenario by comparing back return with lay return of that particular selection
2. For a back/lay scenario I then use the following calculations:
 2.1 hedgeStake = (backReturn - layReturn) / layPrice
 2.2 profit = layProfit + hedgeStake - backAmount

elements.text:
Thanks for sharing this, it looks a bit different then mine but I think it achieves the same. Later on today I'll try this implementation to see if it makes a difference.
Regarding the scenario I mentioned, the second bet (back over 2.5) is not really to hedge evenly, but it would put both selections on profit, it's the third bet that should do the hedging and I'm not getting it right (apparently) - Given a selection with at least one order
Check if we are on a back/lay or lay/back scenario by comparing back return with lay return of that particular selection
For a back/lay scenario I then use the following calculations:

2.1 hedgeStake = (backReturn - layReturn) / layPrice
 2.2 profit = layProfit + hedgeStake - backAmount

text:
I'm yet to run some more tests on the scenario I mentioned, which is basically:
1. Back under 2.5 
2. Back over 2.5 (after this bet we have a green on each selection, just not even)
3. Hedging bet - > At the moment my cashout mechanism is trying to hedge each selection, so this means two bets to hedge the market, but I think this can be optimised to a single bet (on the selection with the highest profit). My problem with a bet on each selection is that the bet going to the "worst" selection (i.e, odds moving quick on opposite direction) is unlikely to get matched, and if only one of the bets gets matched it means the market won't be on a "all green" situation anymore

elements.text: I'm yet to run some more tests on the scenario I mentioned, which is basically:
Back over 2.5 (after this bet we have a green on each selection, just not even)

Hedging bet - > At the moment my cashout mechanism is trying to hedge each selection, so this means two bets to hedge the market, but I think this can be optimised to a single bet (on the selection with the highest profit). My problem with a bet on each selection is that the bet going to the "worst" selection (i.e, odds moving quick on opposite direction) is unlikely to get matched, and if only one of the bets gets matched it means the market won't be on a "all green" situation anymore
